title: Szabolcs-Szatmár-Bereg County
text:
Szabolcs-Szatmár-Bereg (, ) is an <a href="Counties%20of%20Hungary">administrative county</a> (Hungarian: "megye") in north-eastern <a href="Hungary">Hungary</a>, bordering <a href="Slovakia">Slovakia</a> (<a href="Ko%C5%A1ice%20Region">Košice Region</a>), <a href="Ukraine">Ukraine</a> (<a href="Zakarpattia%20Oblast">Zakarpattia Oblast</a>), and <a href="Romania">Romania</a> (<a href="Bihor%20County">Bihor</a> and <a href="Satu%20Mare%20County">Satu Mare</a> counties). It shares borders with the Hungarian counties <a href="Hajd%C3%BA-Bihar%20County">Hajdú-Bihar</a> and <a href="Borsod-Aba%C3%BAj-Zempl%C3%A9n%20County">Borsod-Abaúj-Zemplén</a>. The capital of Szabolcs-Szatmár-Bereg county is <a href="Ny%C3%ADregyh%C3%A1za">Nyíregyháza</a>.
Szabolcs-Szatmár-Bereg County was organised after <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> from the previous counties <a href="Szatm%C3%A1r">Szatmár</a>-Ugocsa-Bereg and <a href="Szabolcs%20%28county%29">Szabolcs</a>. Before 1991, it was called Szabolcs-Szatmár County.
Geography.
Szabolcs-Szatmár-Bereg is located in the north-eastern tip of <a href="Hungary">Hungary</a>. It borders <a href="Ukraine">Ukraine</a> (<a href="Zakarpattia%20Oblast">Zakarpattia Oblast</a>), <a href="Slovakia">Slovakia</a> (<a href="Ko%C5%A1ice%20Region">Košice Region</a>), and <a href="Romania">Romania</a> (<a href="Bihor%20County">Bihor</a> and <a href="Satu%20Mare%20County">Satu Mare</a> counties), and has good connections both by road and rail. Within Hungary, the county is bordered by <a href="Borsod-Aba%C3%BAj-Zempl%C3%A9n%20County">Borsod-Abaúj-Zemplén County</a> and the <a href="Tisza">Tisza River</a> to the north-west and <a href="Hajd%C3%BA-Bihar%20County">Hajdú-Bihar County</a> to the south-west.
The early Hungarians transformed this region significantly by clearing large areas of forest to make way for <a href="pasture">pasture</a>s and farmland. Approximately 5 to 6 square kilometres of forest were cleared for the construction of the <a href="Szabolcs%20%28village%29">Szabolcs</a> earthwork in the ninth and tenth centuries, and its ruins are still present. The area was the gateway for the Mongol invasion of Hungary in the 1240s, and suffered considerable destruction and population decrease during the raids. With the subsequent development of the country, the region became even more marginalized in the 15th century. Ongoing civil war, <a href="rebellion">rebellion</a>, and war exacted a heavy price and further hindered the region's development.
The county's borders have been altered frequently over the years, its current territory being established in 1950 with the amalgamation of the counties of Szabolcs-Ung and Szatmár-Bereg-Ugocsa.
There are many forests, <a href="Field%20%28agriculture%29">fields</a>, <a href="pasture">pasture</a>s, <a href="meadow">meadow</a>s, and <a href="moorland">moorland</a> forests in the county. The <a href="bog">bog</a> <a href="moss">moss</a> moors at <a href="Csaroda">Csaroda</a>, the Nyíres lake, and the Bábtava lake are especially valuable, as they contain many rare species of fauna and flora.
Szabolcs-Szatmár-Bereg is Hungary's sixth biggest county with a total land area of . From a geographical aspect, it is possible to divide the county into two main regions: The <a href="Upper%20Tisza%20Valley">Upper Tisza Valley</a> and the Nyírség. <a href="Tisza">Tisza</a> is one of the most important rivers of the county, entering Szabolcs-Szatmár-Bereg — and Hungary — at <a href="Tiszabecs">Tiszabecs</a>, and leaving at <a href="Tiszadob">Tiszadob</a>. Its segment in Szabolcs-Szatmár-Bereg county is 235 kilometres long, out of which belongs to the Upper Tisza Valley, reaching the area of <a href="Tokaj">Tokaj</a> and <a href="Rakamaz">Rakamaz</a>. The larger area named the Nyírség is derived from the word nyír meaning <a href="birch">birch</a>, as the region is dominated by birch woodlands. The northern part of Nyírség is covered with sandy forest soils, the southern areas have loose wind-blown sand. Alluvial and meadow soils are found in the Upper Tisza region.
The county has a <a href="continental%20climate">continental climate</a>; it is cooler than the Great Plain because it is further north. Summers are cooler than in other parts of the Plains. Annual <a href="Precipitation%20%28meteorology%29">precipitation</a> is 550–600 millimetres. The higher than average number of days of sunshine make ideal conditions for the growing of tomatoes, sunflower, tobacco, apples, and other fruits such as plums—for which the county is famous, being eaten fresh, dried into prunes (some made into <a href="lekvar">lekvar</a>) and fermented into well-known brandies.
The county has 229 settlements, of which 20 are towns. The county capital and largest city is <a href="Ny%C3%ADregyh%C3%A1za">Nyíregyháza</a> with a population of 116,900 in 2003. The other cities have relatively small populations, only those of <a href="Kisv%C3%A1rda">Kisvárda</a> and <a href="M%C3%A1t%C3%A9szalka">Mátészalka</a> having around 18,000 inhabitants. The eastern part of the county is lightly populated and is dotted with small villages which often have very poor economic conditions.
The Tisza River.
The Upper Tisza region has many streams and rivers, but the Nyírség region has little surface water. The most important of Tisza's tributaries is the river <a href="Some%C8%99">Szamos</a>, which is also characterised by great variations in water volume. There are irrigation systems, a water <a href="barrage%20%28dam%29">barrage</a>, and a hydroelectric power station on the Tisza at <a href="Tiszal%C3%B6k">Tiszalök</a>.
Lakes of various sizes have evolved in sandy areas such as the basin of the Sóstó (Salty lake) of <a href="Ny%C3%ADregyh%C3%A1za">Nyíregyháza</a>, whose <a href="alkaline">alkaline</a>, <a href="hydrogen%20carbonate">hydrogen-carbonate</a>d waters have medicinal qualities. Many water <a href="reservoirs">reservoirs</a> have been built according to local demand. Thermal waters of 55–65 °C can be brought to the surface from wells as shallow as 1,000 metres. The most important thermal water reserves are in Nyíregyháza, Kisvárda, Mátészalka, and Tiszavasvári. The county's <a href="geothermal%20energy">geothermal energy</a> still awaits exploitation.
The county has relatively few mineral reserves. Almost all of the large energy source transport systems cross the county.
Demographics.
In 2015, it had a population of 562,357 and the population density was 92/km².
Ethnicity.
Besides the Hungarian majority, the main minority populations in the county are <a href="Romani%20people%20in%20Hungary">Romani</a> (about 44,000), <a href="Germans%20of%20Hungary">German</a> (about 2,000), and <a href="Ukrainians%20in%20Hungary">Ukrainian</a> (about 1,000).
Total population (2011 census): 559,272
Ethnic groups (2011 census):
About 66,000 people in Szabolcs-Szatmár-Bereg County did not declare their ethnicity during the 2011 census.
Religion.
Religious adherence in the county according to 2011 census:
Economy.
The county borders three countries, and it is the only Hungarian county bordering Ukraine. The railway border crossing towards <a href="Ukraine">Ukraine</a> is well developed; its high capacity is able to meet the requirements of transit and bilateral trade. Following the reconstruction of the road border crossing, the county is also able to cope with increased road transportation.
Several regions in the county have tourism potential, mostly unexploited. Szabolcs-Szatmár-Bereg has several agricultural products of excellent quality, with capacity for higher production. There is an abundance of low-cost, semiskilled labour.
The county's biggest problem is the <a href="economic%20crisis">economic crisis</a>. There is a shortage of local capital and inward investment, which restrains the creation of new jobs, thus the unemployment rate remains the second highest in Hungary. Manufacturing lags the rest of the country, most notably lacking high quality, high value-added products. The marginal soil quality limits the scope of agricultural production to a few products which suffer from shrinking export markets to the east.
It is home to the <a href="Szakoly%20Power%20Plant">Szakoly Power Plant</a>.
Politics.

Municipalities.
Szabolcs-Szatmár-Bereg County has 1 <a href="Town%20with%20county%20rights">urban county</a>, 27 <a href="List%20of%20cities%20and%20towns%20of%20Hungary">towns</a>, 15 large villages and 186 villages.
 municipalities are "large" villages.
